title: A taste for privacy
subtitle: When do people give up their privacy?

intro.value: Spoiler: Privacy depends on who you are and and context.
Privacy depends on who you are and context. Your willingness to share data varies dramatically across different institutions and relationships.
In this survey, we asked people about their relative trust in different institutions.
Lets start with a simple question; how do young people these days set up their privacy settings on social media?
We can see that most college students today set their accounts to private, followed by mixed, then public. Overall, **we find that more social media use leads to less private settings**.
This gives us a first glimpse, but: is social media a good proxy for their broader “taste for privacy”?

steps.value: To investigate that question, we asked a series of questions about how comfortable are each respondent with sharing personally identifiable (PII) data with a a number of institutions, broadly understood. What if the comfort of sharing data with a particular institution is about the distance from self, which we call _privacy construal_.

For instance, here's the circle of trust for all our respondents of how sharing PII with social media platforms. The orange grouping is meant to represent broader categories, such as that institutions handling sensitive data.

One interesting pattern we found is the relationship between how platforms users are using and that of comfort sharing PII with social media platform. In general, we found that single platform users are a little bit less trustful of institution than average.

On the contrary, the more platform people use the most comfortable they are sharing PII with those companies. When using 4 social media platforms, young people will tend to trust more those companies with their PII than the police or their Neighbor!
Alright, lets go back to the average view.

In our survey, we also asked about sexual orientation. For instance, we were interested in the relationship between institutions, such as the Police, and sexual orientation. Here it is for people identifying as straight.
Here's the circles of trust for bisexual people, being almost one rating scale below than straight people.
Notice also how relatives are also less trusted with data.
We have one last bit of story to tell.

Adverse childhood experiences composite score; here we look at an ACE score of 8.
And ACE of 9, the circle of trusts about sharing data with other is now completely upside down. Relatives score lower than employer or researcher.
This is not just about relatives, now being ranked below. Acquaintance are even lower.
Interestingly, non-profits seem to be vital for people experiencing many advese childhood experiences.

But ultimately, the visualization makes clear that there is a large gap in trust between oneself and others, something that needs to be seen and understood by folks and institutions who are collecting information about others. Any discussion of youth privacy must account for context and identity..

conclusion.value: Social media settings gave us one angle, but comfort across contexts shows us a richer picture: privacy is relational and institutional.
Demographic differences reveal that “taste for privacy” is not evenly distributed.
Privacy do depends on who you are and and context.
